refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array with the first row giving the regression coefficients for the independent variables x_m, x_(m-1),...,x_2, x_1 followed by the y-intercept if affine is true.
@{known_y's}: vector of values of dependent variable.
@{known_x's}: array of values of independent variables, defaults to a single vector 1,...,n.
affine: if true, the model contains a constant term, defaults to true.
stats: if true, some additional statistics are provided, defaults to false

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If stats is true, the second row contains the corresponding standard errors of the regression coefficients.In this case, the third row contains the R^2 value and the standard error for the predicted value. The fourth row contains the observed F value and its degrees of freedom. Finally, the fifth row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If affine is false, R^2 is the uncentered version of the coefficient of determination; that is the proportion of the sum of squares explained by the model.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the length of @{known_y's} does not match the corresponding length of @{known_x's}, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGEST function applies the ``least squares'' method to fit an exponential curve of the form y = b * m{1}^x{1} * m{2}^x{2}... to your data.
@{known_x's}: known x-values; if known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
const: if this is false the line will be forced to go through (0,1); defaults to TRUE
stat: If stat is TRUE, extra statistical information will be returned; defaults to FALSE.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Extra statistical information is written below the regression line coefficients in the result array. Extra statistical information consists of four rows of data. In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m1, (m2, ...), b are represented. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_y's and known_x's have unequal number of data points, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGFIT function applies the ``least squares'' method to fit the logarithmic equationy = a + b * ln(sign * (x - c)) , sign = +1 or -1 to your data. The graph of the equation is a logarithmic curve moved horizontally by c and possibly mirrored across the y-axis (if sign = -1).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGFIT returns an array having five columns and one row. `Sign' is given in the first column, `a', `b', and `c' are given in columns 2 to 4. Column 5 holds the sum of squared residuals.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: An error is returned when there are less than 3 different x's or y's, or when the shape of the point cloud is too different from a ``logarithmic'' one.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: You can use the above formula = a + b * ln(sign * (x - c)) or rearrange it to = (exp((y - a) / b)) / sign + c to compute unknown y's or x's, respectively.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This is non-linear fitting by trial-and-error. The accuracy of `c' is: width of x-range -> rounded to the next smaller (10^integer), times 0.000001. There might be cases in which the returned fit is not the best possible.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If p < 0 or p > 1 or stddev <= 0 this function returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If stddev = 0 LOGNORMDIST returns a #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x <= 0, mean < 0 or stddev <= 0 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGREG function transforms your x's to z=ln(x) and applies the ``least squares'' method to fit the linear equation y = m * z + b to your y's and z's --- equivalent to fitting the equation y = m * ln(x) + b to y's and x's. LOGREG returns an array having two columns and one row. m is given in the first column and b in the second.
@{known_x's}: known x-values; if known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
const: If this is FALSE, the curve will be forced to go through [1; 0], i.e., b will be zero. The default is TRUE.
stat: If stat is TRUE, extra statistical information will be returned; defaults to FALSE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Any extra statistical information is written below m and b in the result array. This extra statistical information consists of four rows of data: In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m, b are given. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.The default of stat is FALSE.

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Description

refsect1.title: Description

refsect1.title: Description

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Description

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If significance is less than one, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x exceeds the largest value or is less than the smallest value in array, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x does not match any of the values in array or x matches more than once, this function interpolates the returned value.

refsect1.title: See also

refsect1.title: Description

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If n < k this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Description

upper_limit: upper interval limit, defaults to lower_limit

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the sum of the probabilities in prob_range is not equal to 1 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If any value in prob_range is <=0 or > 1, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x_range and prob_range contain a different number of data entries, this function returns a #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: quart: A number from 0 to 4, indicating which quartile to calculate. A value of 0 causes the smallest value of array to be returned.

refsect1.title: Note

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If quart < 0 or quart > 4, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If quart is not an integer, it is truncated.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LARGE, MAX, MEDIAN, MIN, PERCENTILE, SMALL.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CORREL, COVAR, INTERCEPT, LINEST, LOGEST, PEARSON, SLOPE, STEYX, TREND.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This is only meaningful if the underlying distribution really has a third moment. The skewness of a symmetric (e.g., normal) distribution is zero.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If less than three numbers are given, this function returns a #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If less than two numbers are given, SKEWP returns a #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_x or known_y contains no data entries or different number of data entries, this function returns a #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the variance of the known_x is zero, this function returns #DIV/0 error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If data set is empty this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If k <= 0 or k is greater than the number of data items given this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The data points given in array are assumed to be the result of grouping data into intervals of length interval
interval: length of each grouping interval, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If array is empty, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If interval <= 0, this function returns a #NUM! error.SSMEDIAN does not check whether the data points are at least interval apart.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: mean: mean of the original distribution
stddev: standard deviation of the original distribution

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If stddev is 0 this function returns a #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEV is also known as the N-1-standard deviation. Under reasonable conditions, it is the maximum-likelihood estimator for the true population standard deviation.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: To obtain the population standard deviation of a whole population use STDEVP.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: AVERAGE, DSTDEV, DSTDEVP, STDEVA, STDEVPA, VAR.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEVA is also known as the N-1-standard deviation. Under reasonable conditions, it is the maximum-likelihood estimator for the true population standard deviation.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: To obtain the population standard deviation of a whole population use STDEVPA.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is also known as the N-standard deviation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is also known as the N-standard deviation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_y's and known_x's are empty or have a different number of arguments then this function returns a #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The survival function is 1 minus the cumulative distribution function.
dof: number of degrees of freedom
tails: 1 or 2. If this is 2, x is replaced by the absolute value and the returned value is multiplied by 2

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If dof < 1 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If tails is neither 1 or 2 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The parameterization of this function is different from what is used for, e.g., NORMSDIST. This is a common source of mistakes, but necessary for compatibility.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible for non-negative x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The survival function is 1 minus the cumulative distribution function.
dof: number of degrees of freedom

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If p < 0 or p > 1 or dof < 1 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The parameterization of this function is different from what is used for, e.g., NORMSINV. This is a common source of mistakes, but necessary for compatibility.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: @{known_x's}: known x-values; if known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
@{new_x's}: x-values for which you want to estimate the y-values; defaults to known_x's
const: if this is false the line will be forced to go through the origin; defaults to TRUE

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If @{known_y's} and @{known_x's} have unequal number of data points, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If fraction=0.2 and the data set contains 40 numbers, 8 numbers are trimmed from the data set (40 x 0.2): the 4 largest and the 4 smallest. To avoid a bias, the number of points to be excluded is always rounded down to the nearest even number.
ref: list of numbers whose mean you want to calculate
fraction: fraction of the data set excluded from the mean

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: array1: sample from the first population
array2: sample from the second population
tails: number of tails to consider
type: Type of test to perform. 1 indicates a test for paired variables, 2 a test of unpaired variables with equal variances, and 3 a test of unpaired variables with unequal variances

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the data sets contain a different number of data points and the test is paired (type one), TTEST returns the #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: tails and type are truncated to integers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If tails is not one or two, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is any other than one, two, or three, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VAR is also known as the N-1-variance. Under reasonable conditions, it is the maximum-likelihood estimator for the true variance.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARA is also known as the N-1-variance. Under reasonable conditions, it is the maximum-likelihood estimator for the true variance

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: To get the true variance of a complete population use VARPA.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARP is also known as the N-variance.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARPA is also known as the N-variance.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If the cumulative boolean is true it will return: 1 - exp (-(x/beta)^alpha),otherwise it will return (alpha/beta^alpha) * x^(alpha-1) * exp(-(x/beta^alpha)).
cumulative: whether to evaluate the density function or the cumulative distribution function

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x < 0 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If alpha <= 0 or beta <= 0 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: x: mean as given in the null hypothesis
stddev: population stadard deviation, defaults to the sample standard deviation

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If ref contains less than two data items ZTEST returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CONFIDENCE, NORMDIST, NORMINV, NORMSDIST, NORMSINV, STANDARDIZE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASC converts full-width katakana and ASCII characters to half-width equivalent characters, copying all others.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The distinction between half-width and full-width characters is described in http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr11/.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While in obsolete encodings ASC used to translate between 2-byte and 1-byte characters, this is not the case in UTF-8.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHAR(x) returns the CP1252 (Windows-1252) character with code x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: x must be in the range 1 to 255.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CP1252 (Windows-1252) is also known as the "ANSI code page", but it is not an ANSI standard.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CP1252 (Windows-1252) is based on an early draft of ISO-8859-1, and contains all of its printable characters (but partially at different positions.)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In CP1252 (Windows-1252), 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 do not have matching characters.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: For x from 1 to 255 except 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 we have CODE(CHAR(x))=x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CLEAN removes non-printable characters from its argument leaving only regular characters and white-space.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: c must be a valid CP1252 (Windows-1252) character.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CP1252 (Windows-1252) is also known as the "ANSI code page", but it is not an ANSI standard.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CP1252 (Windows-1252) is based on an early draft of ISO-8859-1, and contains all of its printable characters (but partially at different positions.)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In CP1252 (Windows-1252), 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 do not have matching characters.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: For x from 1 to 255 except 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 we have CODE(CHAR(x))=x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: start: starting byte position, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: FIND, LEFTB, RIGHTB, LENB, LEFT, MID, RIGHT, LEN.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: JIS converts half-width katakana and ASCII characters to full-width equivalent characters, copying all others.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The distinction between half-width and full-width characters is described in http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr11/.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While in obsolete encodings JIS used to translate between 1-byte and 2-byte characters, this is not the case in UTF-8.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: num_chars: the number of characters to return (defaults to 1)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the string s is in a right-to-left script, the returned first characters are from the right of the string.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: MID, RIGHT, LEN, MIDB, RIGHTB, LENB.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: num_bytes: the maximum number of bytes to return (defaults to 1)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the string is in a right-to-left script, the returned first characters are from the right of the string.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: MIDB, RIGHTB, LENB, LEFT, MID, RIGHT, LEN.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LEFT, RIGHT, LEN, LEFTB, MIDB, RIGHTB, LENB.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: start_pos: the number of the byte with which to start (defaults to 1)
num_bytes: the maximum number of bytes to return (defaults to 1)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LEFTB, RIGHTB, LENB, LEFT, MID, RIGHT, LEN.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: REPLACEB replaces the string of valid unicode characters starting at the byte start and ending at start+num-1 with the string new.
num: number of bytes to be replaced

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: num_chars: the number of characters to return (defaults to 1)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the string s is in a right-to-left script, the returned last characters are from the left of the string.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LEFT, MID, LEN, LEFTB, MIDB, RIGHTB, LENB.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: num_bytes: the maximum number of bytes to return (defaults to 1)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the string s is in a right-to-left script, the returned last characters are from the left of the string.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LEFTB, MIDB, LENB, LEFT, MID, RIGHT, LEN.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: search may contain wildcard characters (*) and question marks (?). A question mark matches any single character, and a wildcard matches any string including the empty string. To search for * or ?, precede the symbol with ~.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This search is not case sensitive.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If search is not found, SEARCH returns #VALUE!

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If start is less than one or it is greater than the length of text, SEARCH returns #VALUE!

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: search may contain wildcard characters (*) and question marks (?). A question mark matches any single character, and a wildcard matches any string including the empty string. To search for * or ?, precede the symbol with ~.
start: starting byte position, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This search is not case sensitive.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If search is not found, SEARCH returns #VALUE!

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If start is less than one or it is greater than the byte length of text, SEARCH returns #VALUE!

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This array function returns the Fourier or inverse Fourier transform of the given data sequence.
Sequence: the data sequence to be transformed
Inverse: if false, the inverse Fourier transform is calculated. Defaults to false

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The output consists always of one column of complex numbers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If Sequence is neither an n by 1 nor 1 by n array, this function returns #NUM!

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If an interpolation method is used, the number of returned values is one less than the number of targets and the targets values must be given in increasing order.
abscissas: The abscissas of the data to interpolate.
ordinates: The ordinates of the data to interpolate.
targets: The abscissas of the interpolated data.
interpolation: The method of interpolation to be used, defaults to no interpolation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The output consists always of one column of numbers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells in abscissas and ordinates are ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If several target data are provided they must be in the same column in consecutive cells.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If an interpolation method is used, the number of returned values is one less than the number of targets and the targets values must be given in increasing order.
ordinates: The ordinates of the data to interpolate.
filter: Window function to be used, defaults to no window function.
abscissas: The abscissas of the data to interpolate, defaults to regularly spaced abscissa.
interpolation: The method of interpolation to be used, defaults to no interpolation
number: Number of interpolated data points to be used.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The output consists always of one column of numbers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells in abscissas and ordinates are ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If several target data are provided they must be in the same column in consecutive cells.
